awd_titl_txt: CAREER: MicroRNA pathways controlling development after diapause in C. elegans
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

In nature, animals grow up in different and often changing environments.  Harsh environments such as cold weather or inadequate food can cause animals to slow their growth or even pause growth altogether.  Despite this severe interruption to their development, if the environment improves, animals will continue their growth and ultimately become normal adults.  The genes and proteins that allow animals to develop normally after a long interruption are unknown and are a major knowledge gap.  This project builds on previous work from the PI to study this question in the microscopic nematode C. elegans.  These worms are a valuable model because of their simplicity and ease of use for experiments.  Furthermore, C. elegans shares 7,663 genes with humans, meaning that what we learn from C. elegans is often relevant across species.  As part of this study, a new program will engage student teachers in research.  This program will foster teacher-leaders who will then provide effective STEM education at the K-12 level.  This education is critical for the US to maintain its leadership in scientific disciplines, and to provide students with skills that employers value.  Furthermore, this study will result in the training of many undergraduate and graduate students, both in the PI's research lab and in lab-based courses taught by the PI.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:

The proposed work capitalizes on the power of C. elegans as a model to elucidate mechanisms that enable development to occur normally after diapause.  In favorable environments, C. elegans develops continuously through four larval stages separated by molts.  In contrast, adverse environments promote entry into diapause ("dauer") midway through larval development.  Despite this interruption, if favorable conditions are again encountered, development proceeds normally due to the modulation of developmental pathways and re-setting of cell fate.  Prior work from the PI indicates that the potentiation of microRNA activity is a key component of the post-dauer developmental program.  This project builds on that work to discover and characterize factors involved in post-dauer microRNA pathways.  Preliminary data suggest that two transcription factors, ZTF-16 and FOXO/DAF-16, are important players in the post-dauer pathway. Genetic and molecular experiments will test the hypotheses that ZTF-16 is a microRNA target and that FOXO/DAF-16 is a modulator of microRNA activity.  In addition, genomic approaches will identify factors that enable proper post-dauer development.  Completing this project will define mechanisms by which microRNA pathways that control cell fate are modulated after dauer and lay the foundation for future work.

por.por_cntn:
Adult animals are formed by an intricate process of development, whereby cells divide and specialize over time. In nature, development occurs under variable and often unpredictable environmental conditions. In order to survive adverse environments, some animals can pause their development by entering a stress-resistant stage called diapause. How the developing animal adapts to this interruption to become a healthy adult is not understood and was the focus of this project.

To study how diapause affects development, we used the microscopic nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, for which powerful genetic and molecular tools exist. In favorable environments, C. elegans develops continuously through four larval stages before reaching adulthood. However, in adverse environments, larval development can be interrupted by entering a diapause stage called dauer. Dauer larvae are stress resistant and can withstand harsh conditions. If dauer larvae find favorable environments, they can recover and complete development as post-dauer animals. Thus, there are two ways of reaching adulthood, called developmental trajectories, both of which produce healthy adults (Figure 1). Strikingly, although the outcome of development is comparable in both cases, the genes involved are altered. In other words, there are two genetic paths to reach the same end point.

To compare continuous and dauer developmental trajectories, we focused on a group of stem-cell-like cells in the worm skin that divide to produce different skin cell types during larval development. These cells stop dividing at adulthood and take on adult characteristics. The switch from larval to adult characteristics is regulated by genes called “heterochronic” and is understood in detail during continuous development. Mutations in some heterochronic genes cause a phenotype where adult characteristics occur prematurely in larvae. Surprisingly, these same mutations do not cause this phenotype in post-dauer animals, suggesting that these genes are only important during continuous development and that other genes might be important after dauer. Furthermore, part of this genetic difference seems to be related to the action of microRNAs, small RNA molecules that silence the expression of other genes. Certain microRNAs are heterochronic factors that promote adult characteristics. In this project, we deciphered roles for two new heterochronic genes that act during the dauer developmental trajectory and identified new genes that regulate microRNAs after dauer.

The two genes we characterized were daf-16, called FOXO in other species, and ztf-16, both of which encode transcription factors, proteins that turn genes on or off. FOXO is one of the few genes known to regulate diapause across species, and daf-16 promotes dauer formation in C. elegans. By examining the expression of adult characteristics in wild-type and mutant strains, we found that daf-16 coordinates the decision to enter dauer diapause with blocking adult characteristics in dauer larvae. We compared gene expression in daf-16 mutant dauer larvae to controls, created strains with different combinations of mutations, and probed the expression of key heterochronic genes to define the mechanism by which daf-16 regulates adult characteristics during dauer. Using similar techniques, we found that ztf-16 blocks the expression of adult characteristics in both continuously developing and post-dauer larvae, making ztf-16 the first heterochronic gene that equally affects both continuous and dauer developmental trajectories. We found that daf-16 and ztf-16 each act through a combination of known heterochronic genes and novel factors to block adult cell fate during or after dauer.

Our prior work suggested that microRNA activity is enhanced after dauer, and that this enhancement is important for healthy development. We therefore used two methods to search for new genes that interact with microRNAs in the dauer developmental trajectory. First, our collaborators identified proteins that bind to the microRNA silencing complex during and after dauer. Second, we used a genetic screen to find genes that are needed for worms with compromised microRNA function to develop into healthy adults after dauer. Part of this screen was performed by undergraduate students enrolled in an upper-level genetics course taught by the PI, expanding the opportunity for undergraduate students to participate in research.

Five graduate students, 17 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student contributed to this project. These students gave numerous presentations at scientific conferences and are co-authors on the resulting publications. In addition, we developed a program to provide authentic research experiences to undergraduate students studying to become science teachers. Students who participated in this program improved in their ability to design lesson plans, their understanding of inquiry-based science instruction, and confidence in their science teaching ability. Most of the participating students are now full-time science teachers.
